message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Runtime Assurance for Safety-Critical Systems: An Introduction to Safety Filtering Approaches for Complex Control Systems
Paper Abstract: More than three miles above the Arizona desert, an F-16 student pilot experienced a gravity-induced loss of consciousness, passing out while turning at nearly 9Gs (nine times the force of gravity), flying over 400 kn (over 460 mi/h). With its pilot unconscious, the aircraft turn devolved into a dive, dropping from over 17,000 ft to lower than 8,000 ft in altitude in less than 10 s. An auditory warning in the cockpit called out to the pilot “altitude, altitude” just before he crossed through 11,000 ft, switching to a command to “pull up” around 8,000 ft. Meanwhile, the student’s instructor was watching the event unfold from his own aircraft. As the student’s aircraft passed through 12,500 ft, the instructor called over the radio “two recover,” commanding the student (“two”) to end the dive. As the student’s aircraft passed through 11,000 ft, the instructor’s “two recover!” came with increased urgency. At 9,000 ft, and with terror rising in his voice, the instructor yelled “TWO RECOVER!” Fortunately, at the same time as the instructor’s third panicked radio call, a new runtime assurance (RTA) system kicked in to automatically recover the aircraft. The Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System (Auto GCAS), an RTA system integrated on the jets fewer than two years earlier, in fall 2014, detected that the aircraft was about to collide, commanded a roll to wings level and pull-up maneuver, and recovered the aircraft fewer than 3,000 ft above the ground. The event described here occurred in May 2016. A video from the event was declassified and publicly released in September 2016, and the footage can be found at [1] . While Auto GCAS monitored the behavior of a safety-critical cyberphysical system with a ­human ­providing the primary control functions, the same concept is gaining attention in the autonomy community looking to assure safety while integrating complex and intelligent control system designs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about Runtime Assurance:

## Overview

While the exact term "Runtime Assurance" isn't explicitly defined in the results, it appears to be related to several closely connected concepts:

### Runtime Verification

Runtime verification is a computing system analysis and execution approach based on extracting information from a running system and using it to detect and possibly react to observed behaviors satisfying or violating certain properties.(no content)Runtime verification avoids the complexity of traditional formal verification techniques, such as model checking and theorem proving, by analyzing only one or a few execution traces and by working directly with the actual system, thus scaling up relatively well and giving more confidence in the results of the analysis.

### Runtime Error Detection

Runtime error detection is a software verification method that analyzes a software application as it executes and reports defects that are detected during that execution.(no content)Runtime error detection can identify defects that manifest themselves only at runtime (for example, file overwrites) and zeroing in on the root causes of the application crashing, running slowly, or behaving unpredictably.

### Software Assurance

More broadly, software assurance aims to ensure that software is free from vulnerabilities and functions as intended, conforming to all requirements and standards governing the software development process.

Runtime Assurance appears to combine these concepts—using runtime verification and monitoring techniques as part of a broader software assurance strategy to ensure system reliability and safety during execution.

I've performed a web search for "Autonomous Systems." The results cover several meanings of the term, depending on the context:

## Main Interpretations of Autonomous Systems

**Internet/Networking:** An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.(no content)As of 2025, there are roughly 120,000 allocated ASNs.

**Robotics:** An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. Systems such as Motivity can rely on different sensors in different areas, depending upon which provides the most reliable data at the time, and can re-map a building autonomously.

**Mathematics:** In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

**Decentralized Systems:** An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

The term "autonomous systems" can apply to many different fields, from computer networks and robotics to mathematics and software architecture.

Links: [{"title":"Cyber-physical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyber-physical_system"},{"title":"Cyber-kinetic attack - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyber-kinetic_attack"},{"title":"Brij B. Gupta - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brij_B._Gupta"},{"title":"Cyber espionage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyber_espionage"},{"title":"Cyberwarfare and Iran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyberwarfare_by_Iran"},{"title":"Cyber Citizen Shockman Zero - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyber_Citizen_Shockman_Zero"}]

Here are the search results for Cyber-physical Systems:

## Overview

Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are mechanisms controlled and monitored by computer algorithms, tightly integrated with the internet and its users.(no content)In cyber-physical systems, physical and software components are deeply intertwined, able to operate on different spatial and temporal scales, exhibit multiple and distinct behavioral modalities, and interact with each other in ways that change with context.

## Key Characteristics

CPS involves transdisciplinary approaches, merging theory of cybernetics, mechatronics, design and process science.(no content)CPS is also similar to the Internet of Things (IoT), sharing the same basic architecture; nevertheless, CPS presents a higher combination and coordination between physical and computational elements.

## Applications and Examples

Examples of CPS include smart grid, autonomous automobile systems, medical monitoring, industrial control systems, robotics systems, recycling and automatic pilot avionics.(no content)Precursors of cyber-physical systems can be found in areas as diverse as aerospace, automotive, chemical processes, civil infrastructure, energy, healthcare, manufacturing, transportation, entertainment, and consumer appliances.

## System Architecture

Unlike more traditional embedded systems, a full-fledged CPS is typically designed as a network of interacting elements with physical input and output instead of as standalone devices.

Here are the search results for Cyber-physical Systems:

## Overview

Cyber-physical systems (CPS) are mechanisms controlled and monitored by computer algorithms, tightly integrated with the internet and its users.(no content)In cyber-physical systems, physical and software components are deeply intertwined, able to operate on different spatial and temporal scales, exhibit multiple and distinct behavioral modalities, and interact with each other in ways that change with context.

## Key Characteristics

CPS involves transdisciplinary approaches, merging theory of cybernetics, mechatronics, design and process science.(no content)CPS is also similar to the Internet of Things (IoT), sharing the same basic architecture; nevertheless, CPS presents a higher combination and coordination between physical and computational elements.

## Applications and Examples

Examples of CPS include smart grid, autonomous automobile systems, medical monitoring, industrial control systems, robotics systems, recycling and automatic pilot avionics.(no content)Precursors of cyber-physical systems can be found in areas as diverse as aerospace, automotive, chemical processes, civil infrastructure, energy, healthcare, manufacturing, transportation, entertainment, and consumer appliances.

## System Architecture

Unlike more traditional embedded systems, a full-fledged CPS is typically designed as a network of interacting elements with physical input and output instead of as standalone devices.

## Internet Content Filtering

An Internet filter is a type of internet censorship that restricts or controls the content an Internet user is capable to access, especially when utilized to restrict material delivered over the Internet via the Web, Email, or other means.(no content)Such restrictions can be applied at various levels: a government can attempt to apply them nationwide, or they can, for example, be applied by an Internet service provider to its clients, by an employer to its personnel, by a school to its students, by a library to its visitors, by a parent to a child's computer, or by an individual user to their own computers.

## School Web Filtering

In educational settings, web filtering in schools blocks students from inappropriate and distracting content across the web, while allowing sites that are selected by school administrators.

## Occupational Safety Filtering

In the context of occupational safety, engineering controls are physical changes to the workplace that isolate workers from hazards by containing them in an enclosure, or removing contaminated air from the workplace through ventilation and filtering.

Web search results for query: "Ground Collision Avoidance"

Links: [{"title":"Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_Ground_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Traffic collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Airborne collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airborne_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Portable collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Ground proximity warning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_proximity_warning_system"},{"title":"TERPROM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TERPROM"},{"title":"Obstacle Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstacle_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Terrain awareness and warning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrain_awareness_and_warning_system"},{"title":"Collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Jameel Janjua - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jameel_Janjua"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Ground Collision Avoidance:

## Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System (Auto-GCAS)

The Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System uses inputs from terrain mapping, aircraft location, and automation to avoid ground collisions.(no content)The Auto-GCAS system detects imminent ground contact and warns the pilot. If there is no pilot response, the Auto-GCAS takes control, maneuvering to avoid ground contact.(no content)The Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System (Auto-GCAS) enhances safety by mitigating controlled flight into terrain (CFIT) accidents.(no content)The Auto-GCAS team was awarded the 2018 Collier Trophy for the design-integration and flight testing in the F-35, marking the year's greatest achievement in aeronautics.

## Other Ground Collision Avoidance Technologies

A Terrain awareness and warning system (TAWS) uses a digital terrain map, together with position information from a navigation system such as GPS, to predict whether the aircraft's current flight path could put it in conflict with obstacles such as mountains or high towers.(no content)TERPROM (terrain profile matching) is a military navigation Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS) employed on aircraft and missiles, which uses stored digital elevation data combined with navigation system and radar altimeter inputs to compute the location of an aircraft or missile above the surface of the Earth. It is also used as a warning system to prevent aircraft from flying too close to the ground.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the F-16 Fighting Falcon:

## Overview

The General Dynamics (now Lockheed Martin) F-16 Fighting Falcon is an American single-engine supersonic multirole fighter aircraft under production by Lockheed Martin.(no content)Designed as an air superiority day fighter, it evolved into a successful all-weather multirole aircraft with over 4,600 built since 1976.

## Current Status

As of 2025, it is the world's most common fixed-wing aircraft in military service, with 2,084 F-16s operational.(no content)Although no longer purchased by the United States Air Force (USAF), improved versions are being built for export.

## Key Features

The F-16's key features include a frameless bubble canopy for enhanced cockpit visibility, a side-stick to ease control while maneuvering, an ejection seat reclined 30 degrees from vertical to reduce the effect of g-forces on the pilot. The fighter has a single turbofan engine, an internal M61 Vulcan cannon and 11 hardpoints.

## Nicknames

Although officially named "Fighting Falcon", the aircraft is commonly known by the nickname "Viper" among its crews and pilots.

## History and Manufacturers

The F-16 Fighting Falcon was manufactured from General Dynamics from 1974 to 1993, Lockheed Corporation from 1993 to 1995, and since 1995, it has been manufactured by Lockheed Martin.

## International Use

The F-16 has also been procured by the air forces of 25 other nations.(no content)F-16s from various US-led coalitions flew combat missions in the Gulf War, Bosnia, Yugoslavia, Afghanistan, Libya, and Iraq and Syria. F-16s have also seen extensive combat use by Israel, Pakistan, and Ukraine.

## Overview

The General Dynamics (now Lockheed Martin) F-16 Fighting Falcon is an American single-engine supersonic multirole fighter aircraft under production by Lockheed Martin.(no content)Designed as an air superiority day fighter, it evolved into a successful all-weather multirole aircraft with over 4,600 built since 1976.

## Current Status

## Key Features

The F-16's key features include a frameless bubble canopy for enhanced cockpit visibility, a side-stick to ease control while maneuvering, an ejection seat reclined 30 degrees from vertical to reduce the effect of g-forces on the pilot. ## Nicknames

Although officially named "Fighting Falcon", the aircraft is commonly known by the nickname "Viper" among its crews and pilots.

## History and Manufacturers

## International Use

Web search results for query: "Control Systems"

Links: [{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Systems control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_control"},{"title":"Systems and Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_and_Control"},{"title":"Industrial control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_control_system"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Category:Air pollution control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Air_pollution_control_systems"},{"title":"Industrial process control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_process_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Smoke control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoke_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"}]

## Search Results for "Control Systems"

I found comprehensive information about control systems. Here's an overview of the key concepts:

### Definition and Basic Concept

A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops.(no content)It can range from a single home heating controller using a thermostat controlling a domestic boiler to large industrial control systems which are used for controlling processes.

### Types of Control Systems

**Closed-Loop vs. Open-Loop:**
A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller. A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

**Common Examples:**
- An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed.

### Industrial Control Systems

An industrial control system (ICS) is an electronic control system and associated instrumentation used for industrial process control.(no content)Larger systems are usually implemented by supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems, or DCSs, and programmable logic controllers (PLCs).

### Control Strategies

Linear control are control systems and control theory based on negative feedback for producing a control signal to maintain the controlled process variable (PV) at the desired setpoint (SP).(no content)Fuzzy logic is an attempt to apply the easy design of logic controllers to the control of complex continuously varying systems. Basically, a measurement in a fuzzy logic system can be partly true. The rules of the system are written in natural language and translated into fuzzy logic.

Web search results for query: "Safety-Critical Systems"

Links: [{"title":"Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-critical_system"},{"title":"Safety-Critical Systems Club - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safety-Critical_Systems_Club"},{"title":"Critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_system"},{"title":"Talk:Safety-critical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Safety-critical_system"},{"title":"Critical Software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_Software"},{"title":"Mission critical - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_critical"},{"title":"Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazard_Analysis_Critical_Control_Point"},{"title":"Redundancy (engineering) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redundancy_(engineering)"},{"title":"Hazard analysis and risk-based preventive controls - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazard_analysis_and_risk-based_preventive_controls"},{"title":"Motor Industry Software Reliability Association - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_Industry_Software_Reliability_Association"}]

Here's the search results for "Safety-Critical Systems":

## Definition and Core Requirements

A safety-critical system is designed to lose less than one life per billion (10^9) hours of operation. More broadly, safety critical systems deal with scenarios that may lead to loss of life, serious personal injury, or damage to the natural environment.

## Design Methods

Typical design methods include probabilistic risk assessment, a method that combines failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) with fault tree analysis.(no content)Safety-critical systems are increasingly computer-based.

## Types of Reliability Approaches

Safety-critical systems employ different reliability strategies:

- Fail-operational systems continue to operate when their control systems fail. Examples of these include elevators, the gas thermostats in most home furnaces, and passively safe nuclear reactors.

- Fail-soft systems are able to continue operating on an interim basis with reduced efficiency in case of failure. Most spare tires are an example of this: They usually come with certain restrictions (e.g. a speed restriction) and lead to lower fuel economy.

- Fault-tolerant systems avoid service failure when faults are introduced to the system. An example may include control systems for ordinary nuclear reactors. The normal method to tolerate faults is to have several computers continually test the parts of a system, and switch on hot spares for failing subsystems.

## Software Engineering Standards

Standards exist for industry, in general, (IEC 61508) and automotive (ISO 26262), medical (IEC 62304) and nuclear (IEC 61513) industries specifically.

## Examples

Examples of safety-critical systems are a control system for a chemical manufacturing plant, aircraft, the controller of an unmanned train metro system, and many others across various industries.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
